title: What made Paul Simon’s album “Graceland” so phenomenal? - Quora

response.answer_text: Phenomenal? Well that’s totally subjective. I think its a very good album, I think Paul is a fantastic lyricist and an extremely talented musician. I don’t think this album is his best, maybe not even top three. I find I enjoy his work in Simon and Garfunkel better than his solo work, although I am certainly not knocking his solo work at all. Paul is among the top songwriters like Bob Dylan and Bruce Springsteen in his ability to convey so much, to tell such a complete story in a few words. His use of the South African Musicians he employed on this album certainly deserves recognition, it was full of new dynamic sounds for him and very, very good.

The mixture of the very poppy sound and the South Africa controversy, which put Graceland in the headlines. Personally, I prefer Paul’s later solo albums or his S&G work. Graceland is undeniably good and sometimes great - but it is not great throughout, IMO. In places it feels forced and even a little cheesy to me.

Great songs make a great album. The world music flavors, that were not specific to one style, were incorporated to the needs of the individual songs. It was a big jump from the top forty material Paul was cranking out, and lyrically, the songs had more depth.

The fact that it’s only a tenth as good as the record that followed it, Rhythm of the Saints - a work of unalloyed genius from start to finish. Graceland is amazing, wonderful, new, gorgeous, intricate, clever, packed with wonder. Its follow-up is all that but … more so.

Paul Simon's 'Graceland': 10 Things You Didn't Know If you're interested in a long and informative read check out the article in Rolling Stone. Reading through it you can see how many thought Graceland was so influential, political, and phenominal at the time.
